conclusion: The v-t graph shows two curves, one for object A and one for object B, both starting at the origin and ending at t₁.
Object A's velocity curve is always above object B's velocity curve from 0 to t₁.
Object A’s velocity is larger than object B’s at every moment from t = 0 to t₁.
The displacement difference Δs(t) equals the time-integral of the velocity difference between two objects.
The derivative of the displacement difference Δs(t) is Δs′(t) = v_A(t) − v_B(t) > 0 for 0 < t < t₁.
A strictly positive derivative means Δs(t) grows monotonically and continuously throughout the interval.
The separation in displacement between the two objects is necessarily (strictly) increasing from 0 to t₁.
